snippet: Cutting out the middlemen could drive down the price of oil by as much as 40 percent and the price of gasoline by as much as $1 a gallon.
abstract: Op-Ed article by former Rep Joseph P Kennedy II calls for legislation that would ban oil speculators from commodity exchanges in America; charges that cutting out the middlemen could drive down the price of oil by as much as 40 percent and the price of gasoline by as much as $1 a gallon.

headline.main: The High Cost of Gambling on Oil
headline.print_headline: The High Cost of Gambling on Oil

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)

snippet: Mr. Tramiel championed Commodore computers, inexpensive machines that were to personal computers what Henry Ford’s Model T was to automobiles.
abstract: Jack Tramiel, personal computer pioneer, dies at age 83.

headline.main: Jack Tramiel, a Pioneer in Computers, Dies at 83
headline.print_headline: Jack Tramiel, a Pioneer in Computers, Dies at 83

snippet: A federal court awarded nearly $250,000 to six salon workers who united to sue the owners of a Long Island chain.
abstract: Federal jury awards nearly $250,000 to six nail salon workers who sued the owners of Babi Nails, chain of Long Island salons, saying they were paid below minimum wage and forced to toil in an abusive environment; victory coincides with a push to organize by salon workers across New York City, a largely immigrant workforce that is growing more assertive.

headline.main: Saying Court Win Helps, Nail Salon Workers Rally
headline.print_headline: Saying Court Win Helps, Nail Salon Workers Rally

snippet: Dozens of corporate boards, including those of Halliburton, Kraft, Home Depot and Waste Management, insist or recommend their chief executives fly on private jets for security reasons. It’s a common corporate tax trick.
abstract: Dozens of corporate boards, including those of Halliburton, Kraft, Home Depot and Waste Management, insist or recommend their chief executives fly on private jets for security reasons. It’s a common corporate tax trick.

headline.main: For Some Corporate Chiefs, Private Security Is a Tax Break
headline.print_headline: Deal Professor: For Some Corporate Chiefs, Private Security Is a Tax Break

snippet: The news of Instagram's sale brings a sharper reality into focus - that the secluded and private corners of the Web where we can let our hair down and be our authentic selves are fewer and farther between with each passing day.
abstract: The news of Instagram's sale brings a sharper reality into focus - that the secluded and private corners of the Web where we can let our hair down and be our authentic selves are fewer and farther between with each passing day.

headline.main: Digital Diary: Instagram and the Internet's 'Secret' Places
headline.print_headline: Sense of Privacy Dwindles a Bit

snippet: Asheem Chandna, a partner at Greylock Partners, is a board member at Imperva and Palo Alto Networks and an investor in more than a dozen security-focused start-ups. He talks about how the nature of the cybersecurity threat is changing and what opp...
abstract: Asheem Chandna, a partner at Greylock Partners, is a board member at Imperva and Palo Alto Networks and an investor in more than a dozen security-focused start-ups. He talks about how the nature of the cybersecurity threat is changing and what opportunities lie ahead.

headline.main: One on One: Asheem Chandna, Venture Capitalist

snippet: The electronics giant, already battered by a number of factors, doubled its projected net loss for the business year that just ended because of an additional tax expense.
abstract: Sony more than doubles its projected net loss for the past fiscal year to 520 billion yen ($6.4 billion), its worst loss ever, as an additional tax expense hurt the already battered company; Sony has suffered in the past year from heavy losses in its television business, a strong yen and natural disasters in Japan and elsewhere overseas.

headline.main: Sony Revises Expected Loss to $6.4 Billion
headline.print_headline: Sony Doubles Its 2012 Loss Forecast and Hints at More Layoffs

snippet: Corrections appearing in print on April 10, 2012.
